webTitle: Europe's banking regulator to relax cap on bonuses for highest-paid staff

fields.standfirst: Plans to lift pay restrictions from 12,000 bankers have angered campaigners but are welcomed by industry figures
fields.body:
Europe's banking watchdog has watered down its proposals on the controversial bonus cap potentially allowing an estimated 12,000 highly paid bankers to avoid the limit on their pay.

As major banks prepare to offer their highest paid staff top-up payments to skirt round the cap, the European Banking Authority has changed its definition of the group of bankers that would be subject to the plan to limit bonuses to 100% of salary from January 1.

In May the EBA had proposed that anyone earning over €500,000 (£425,000) would automatically face the restriction but on Friday removed this stipulation, angering union officials facing cuts to staff at high street banks.

Unite national officer Dominic Hook said: "People at the top of the banks get treated completely differently to people at the bottom. We need rules."

Campaigners for a tax on financial transactions urged Europe to stand firm against lobbying from the banking industry. David Hillman, Robin Hood Tax campaign spokesman, said: "Relaxing the cap on bankers' bonuses at a time when millions are still suffering the costs of the economic crisis is a step in the wrong direction."

Under the latest proposal, banks will be able to tell their domestic regulators – the Prudential Regulation Authority in the UK – that they are exempting staff earning up to €750,000 if they are not deemed to be taking or managing risks for the bank. Between €750,000 and up to €1m the banks will have to seek approval from their regulator to exempt staff from the bonus cap. Exemption for staff earning more than €1m will need explicit EBA approval.

The chancellor George Osborne has launched a legal challenge to the cap, which has prompted banks to find ways to keep offering big pay deals. Barclays, for example, is offering an additional payment - known as role based pay - which will be paid alongside salary.

Under the original plans, banks will be able to pay 200% of salary in bonus with shareholders' approval.

"These are sensible changes to the rules," said Jon Terry, a partner at accountants PricewaterhouseCoopers. "Overall we think it's likely these rules will continue to capture high earning traders. But there may be the opportunity to exclude people who don't put the firm's capital at risk, such as back-office staff, analysts, or portfolio managers in banks' asset management businesses."

Data released by the EBA last month showed the impact the cap would have on City bankers. More than 2,700 individuals in the City received more than €1m in 2012 and their average bonuses were 370% of their salaries.

Other banks may increase salaries. Andrew Stanger, partner at lawyers Mayer Brown, said that a fall in bankers hit by the cap could help avoid a rise in fixed costs, such as salaries.

But he added: "There may however be some disappointed bankers who were looking forward to a higher proportion of guaranteed remuneration, free of the uncertainties of the performance targets and forfeiture provisions commonly applied to deferred bonuses."

webTitle: Scottish Power cancels £5.4bn Argyll Array offshore wind farm plan

fields.standfirst: Project that would have been world's largest and provided green energy to 1m homes deemed 'not financially viable'
fields.body:
Scottish Power has abandoned a £5.4bn plan to build the world's largest offshore wind farm, after four years of planning, because it is "not financially viable".

The decision not to go ahead with the Argyll Array, which would have provided green energy for 1 million homes, is another blow to the government's plans to tackle a looming supply problem and to meet its low carbon targets.

RWE, another of the big six power companies, announced two weeks ago that it was abandoning plans to construct a £4bn offshore wind farm, the Atlantic Array, off Devon. On Thursday, Centrica, owner of British Gas, announced it was selling its stake in another huge offshore wind farm, Race Bank, off East Anglia.

But the Scottish Power move is a particular setback because the company admits that the conditions at Argyll Array, off the coast of Tiree in the Inner Hebrides, are some of the best in the UK. It is a favourite spot for windsurfers. The wind farm was to have up to 300 turbines capable of producing 1,800 megawatts, three times more than the current largest wind farm – the London Array, off Kent – and almost 60% of the output of EDF's planned new Hinkley Point C nuclear plant. Energy groups have complained that the subsidies available for new wind projects are not high enough. Many have also warned that the lights could go off without more power capacity.

Jonathan Cole, head of offshore wind at Scottish Power, said: "We believe it is possible to develop the Argyll Array site; it has some of the best wind conditions of any offshore zone in the UK. However, it is our view that the Argyll Array project is not financially viable in the short term.

"The rate of progress in development of foundation and installation technology has been slower than anticipated."

Scottish Power said the main problems affecting the project were the ground conditions on the site, particularly the presence of hard rock, coupled with challenging wave conditions that could make construction more difficult. It also blamed the presence of basking sharks, which environmental groups continue to study to get a greater understanding of their activities in the area.

The wind farm has long been the target of a No Tiree Array group, which yesterday welcomed the decision by the developer, calling the plans an "environmental disaster for Tiree and the west coast of Scotland".

Earlier this week, Keith Anderson, chief corporate officer of Scottish Power, argued that the "carbon price floor", which taxes companies for burning fossil fuels, should be shelved by the government because it would make the UK's remaining coal plants largely uneconomic by the middle of the decade. With Britain's spare power margin already forecast to fall as low as 2% by 2015, the carbon tax would force more closures and "threatens to make us even more vulnerable to the risk of blackouts".

Scottish Power, owned by Iberdrola of Spain, also warned recently that Ed Miliband's promise to freeze domestic power prices in a bid to help struggling consumers risked discouraging further investment. It said it would continue to show its commitment to UK offshore wind, with the much smaller 389MW West of Duddon Sands project currently under construction in the Irish Sea.

An application for consent was also submitted in 2012 with Vattenfall for the East Anglia ONE offshore windfarm, which could have a capacity of up to 1,200MW.

RenewableUK, the lobby group for wind power, played down the Argyll Array decision. Maf Smith, the organisation's deputy chief executive said: "The fact that not all wind farm projects go ahead is a natural part of the development process. Some encounter physical obstacles or financial challenges which mean that they aren't viable for the time being – although they will be in the future, as cutting-edge wind turbine technology is developing at an astonishing rate."

webTitle: Who was responsible for Lloyds' crass bonus scheme? Don't ask the FCA | Nils Pratley

fields.standfirst: Despite dishing out a £28m mis-selling fine, the Financial Conduct Authority doesn't seem interested in accountability
fields.body:
Two questions stand out from this week's £28m slap on the wrist for Lloyds Banking Group. First, how could anybody of seniority at Lloyds in 2010 or 2011 have thought it a good idea to threaten staff with demotion if they didn't meet a quota for stuffing customers with investment products? Second, why doesn't the Financial Conduct Authority think it important to find out who at the bank approved and encouraged a crass incentive scheme that also offered "grand in the hand" bonuses to super-salesmen?

Remember the context. In late 2009 Lloyds, freshly bailed-out by the state, had completed its takeover of HBOS. It was a moment to impose common standards on the new banking beast and recognise that those newly minted pledges about treating customers fairly would require a dose of caution.

Yet managers in January 2010 introduced revamped schemes that offered pots of gold and promotion to salesmen who helped to meet group targets, and threatened the lazy and the scrupulous with demotion and pay cuts. A 10-year-old could have spotted the danger that mis-selling would follow.

By March 2011 the bank had yet another prompt to examine itself. António Horta-Osório had arrived as chief executive and, in almost his first act, declared that Lloyds' past mis-selling of payment protection insurance, or PPI, was a grave wrong that had to be put right. So best to ensure the same thing couldn't happen again, right?

Not exactly – or not immediately. The incentives farce ran until March 2012. The only relief, from Lloyds' point of view, is that the stock market rose and most of the equity-based products did well. Thus the bill for redress should be modest. In that regard, Lloyds was lucky.

"The findings do not make pleasant reading," said Tracey McDermott, the FCA's director of enforcement and financial crime. Yes, but your analysis is not impressive either. The FCA doesn't seem interested in identifying who at Lloyds ordered, or approved, the absurd incentives. In a 35-page report, no names are mentioned. The closest the regulator comes to acknowledging that decisions are taken by people is this passage: "Retail Finance had overall responsibilty for the process, including reviewing and challenging the sales plan and approving the final sales targets. This was subject to supervision and approval by senior management and relevant committees."

Senior management? Relevant committees? What does that mean? Is Helen Weir, head of retail banking until 2011 and now finance director at John Lewis, ultimately responsible? Should Archie Kane, head of the insurance side, carry some of the blame? How about former chief executive Eric Daniels?

Was Horta-Osório, having spotted the seriousness of the PPI scandal, at fault for not ordering an immediate review on incentives in March 2011? Should chairman Sir Win Bischoff have intervened? Did the non-executives on the remuneration committee, led by Anthony Watson, bother to explore incentives outside the boardroom?

Don't ask the FCA or Lloyds, it seems. Instead, shareholders, and the outside world, will have to wait until next spring to learn whose bonuses for 2010, if anybody's, Lloyds claws back. Weir, for example, may still have about £300,000 outstanding from her 2010 award.

In an era when it is agreed that greater boardroom accountability is an important way to make banks behave better, the Lloyds tale is a classic case of responsibility being lost in the wind. The same applies to the £28m fine that Lloyds accurately says "is not expected to have a material impact on the group". Feeble.

RSA chief quits

Farewell Simon Lee, we hardly knew you. Two years into the job, the chief executive of RSA has had to walk the plank. There can be no complaints: three profit warnings in six weeks, a dividend in peril (again) and the emergency dispatch of £135m across the Irish Sea requires a resignation.

RSA's shares have plunged almost to levels seen a decade ago, when investors were wondering whether the old Royal Insurance and Sun Alliance could ever be successfully welded together. Asbestos claims and a weak stock market didn't help either.

Andy Haste, Lee's predecessor and boss, completed the welding job and, in 2010, confidence was so high that he could make a cheeky approach to Aviva to buy its non-life business. That now seems a long time ago. After the surge in Irish whiplash claims, plus alleged "accounting irregularities" in the Irish unit, RSA is definitely a seller, not a buyer of businesses. That's what "optimising the group's business portfolio", as chairman Martin Scicluna puts it, means.

A radical remedy would see one of the crown jewels – the Canadian and Scandinavian divisions – depart. Or perhaps RSA's need for capital can be met with minor disposals plus a rights issue and a dividend cut. A rights issue is "not our current plan", says Scicluna, keeping his options open.

At this stage, that's the only possible position to adopt. Scicluna, thrust into an executive role, first has to get to the bottom of the crisis in Ireland, still a mystery to shareholders. Then he has to determine how much capital RSA requires and find a chief executive. It's a long to-do list.

If would-be bidders for RSA emerge along the way, one suspects shareholders will demand that Scicluna talk to them. Investors are understandably weary.

Manchester United going down

Would you say Manchester United, the New York-listed company, is worth 20% more than it was a year ago? Minus a long-serving managerial genius, and with the club standing 9th in the Premier League, it is hard to understand why the shares trade at $17, (about £10) versus the $14 at which the Glazer family sold a 10% stake in August last year.

United may yet scramble into a top-four slot this season, ensuring qualification for next year's Champions League, which is where the big bucks are earned. But, even if they do, it's obvious that a hefty bill will have to be paid in the transfer market to improve the squad.

In the age of Gareth Bale, for whom Real Madrid paid £85m, being a forced buyer of top-end footballing talent is not a comfortable position. The Glazers have paid down a lot of debt since their leveraged buyout in 2005, but the company was still carrying net borrowings of £300m at the end of June this year.

Hedge funds, such as Odey, are taking short positions in the shares. There are no open goals in the shorting game, but this one looks attractive. United's stock market value is $2.78bn (£1.7bn). When total revenues are just £400m-ish, and staff routinely consume half, the valuation looks too rich for a business facing a major capital expenditure programme.

Turbulent airports commissioner

Get ready for another round of the great runway debate. It should be worth watching because Sir Howard Davies, head of the airports commission, may have an opinion that ministers, and the Mayor of London, do not like.

Davies will unveil his interim report on Tuesday. As a rule, interim reports skirt around their subject and leave everything up for grabs. Davies may not play ball. He seems determined to advance only a few options for a new runway or runways.

If they all involve expansion at Heathrow, there will be panic in government ranks. Ministers were hoping the politically-toxic issue could be ignored until after the 2015 election, which is when Davies' final report is due. If a new Thames estuary airport gets a thumbs-down, watch Boris Johnson explode.

The view here is that Gatwick is the way to go. Far more important, though, is that Davies says what he actually thinks. Reports of last-minute political lobbying to expand the shortlist are alarming.

webTitle: High-street prices cut as consumer sales fall in first week of December

fields.standfirst: With consumer confidence lagging behind the cost of living, Christmas shoppers are holding out for discounts
fields.body:
High street sales fell unexpectedly in the first week of December as squeezed consumers put off Christmas shopping, a survey indicates. Non-food sales in stores dropped 4.1% in the week ending 8 December, led by a 5.9% fall in fashion buying, figures from the accountant BDO showed. Spending on homewares increased 4.5% and online shopping jumped by 25%.

The figures underscored evidence from individual retailers that the high street is struggling despite predictions of a bumper Christmas fuelled by signs of economic recovery. With more than a week of trading to go, H&M has launched a "winter sale" with price cuts of up to 60%.

The move by the world's second-largest fashion retailer follows big discounts offered by rivals French Connection and House of Fraser this week. Marks & Spencer is offering a 20% discount in-store on non-food items for holders of online vouchers this weekend for the second time in a month, and John Lewis is offering 20% off many items to match competitors' discounts. Surveys have shown consumer confidence surging, but growth is continuing to lag behind price rises in household energy and other key goods.

Callum Butterfield, a market analyst at BDO, said: "People are still poorer than they were 12 months ago. We have seen good economic data and people are feeling more confident but they are not going out to spend more money because they haven't got it."

The government's independent fiscal watchdog has said real wage growth will not pick up substantially until 2016 as earnings increases have been largely eaten up by price rises.

Butterfield said clothing sellers outside the luxury bracket are suffering particularly from the squeeze on middle-income earners' spending power and a lack of stand-out products.

John Lewis said that sales slowed in the week after the period recorded by BDO, which covered "Black Friday" when retailers offered big discounts on 29 November.

The downbeat outlook for Christmas sales raises the prospect of household names falling into administration early in the new year, as happened this year with HMV, Jessops and fashion chain Republic.

Butterfield said: "Directly after Christmas I suspect we will see a few big fall-outs and I'm approaching next year with caution, assuming that consumers still won't have more money to spend."

webTitle: FTSE 100 falls for sixth week in a row on Federal Reserve concerns

fields.bodyText: After a failed attempt at a rally on Friday, leading shares fell for the sixth week in a row, the FTSE 100's worst run since June 2008. The finger of blame was pointed firmly across the Atlantic, with investors increasingly nervous that the US Federal Reserve might begin trimming its $85bn a month bond buying programme at next week's meeting, earlier than previously thought. Growing evidence of a revival in the US economy could force the Fed's hand, particularly since it is due to be Ben Bernanke's last policy get-together before handing the chair over to Janet Yellen. An agreement last week over the US budget was another factor which could prompt the Fed to begin tapering its stimulus package, which has been one of the main factors behind the surge in global stock markets so far this year. webTitle: Bailout exit does not mark end of Ireland's financial crisis, says Noonan

fields.standfirst: As Ireland prepares to become the first country to exit eurozone bailout, there are still several reasons why its finance minister Michael Noonan thinks the crisis is not over just yet
fields.body:
Viewed through the ruthlessly narrow lens of the financial markets, Ireland's rehabilitation has been impressive. Its banks look far healthier than they did at the height of the crisis; modest growth has resumed; and its debt-to-GDP ratio is expected to start declining after peaking this year.

That has helped Ireland's bond yields – in effect the interest rate Dublin must pay on its debts – fall to well below the level faced by the other bailed-out eurozone countries.

But there are at least three reasons finance minister Michael Noonan was right to declare the country's exit from the bailout a milestone, rather than the end of the road.

First, the human cost of the downturn has been immense, and is far from over. Unemployment has started to decline, but is still expected to remain above 13% for at least another 12 months. Property prices appear to be bottoming out, but they halved between 2007 and 2012. And while many countries have got used to wages declining in real terms since the Great Recession, Ireland's workers have had to swallow outright declines in pay, even before the impact of inflation – at the same time as the housing nest egg they may have been counting on evaporated before their eyes.

Second, unlike in Iceland, where there has been large-scale debt forgiveness, consumers and the government in Ireland are still carrying the burden of debts built up during the property boom and the banking crisis, which will weigh on growth for many years to come, and leave the economy vulnerable to currents beyond Dublin's control. The average household has debts worth twice its annual disposable income – well above levels usually considered dangerous.

And third, the markets' relaxed approach to Ireland could evaporate very quickly in the face of a new bout of turmoil elsewhere in the eurozone. The triggers could be many and various – a hitch in plans for banking union; US tapering pushing up bond yields across the board; a political crisis in one of the other bailed-out member states. In calm times, investors are meticulous about differentiating one debt-burdened state from another; in a crisis, those distinctions can rapidly become blurred. In leaving the clutches of the IMF without a safety net, Ireland has taken a bold decision. Only time will tell whether it is justified or reckless.

webTitle: Ireland prepares to exit bailout after 'biggest crisis since the Famine' - as it happened

fields.standfirst:
• Afternoon summary
• Finance ministers hail end of bailout- highlights start here
• But more years of pain ahead
• Ireland 'rioted at the ballot box'
fields.body:
4.16pm GMT

Open thread

Update: we've just launched an open thread where readers can discuss Ireland's bailout exit. It's here:

http://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/dec/13/ireland-exit-bailout-government

Updated at 4.17pm GMT

1.59pm GMT

Irish ministers confirm bailout is over - the key points

After years of covering the eurozone crisis, it's a pleasant change to watch two politicians talk about ending a financial assistance programme, rather than tumbling into one.

But while finance minister Michael Noonan and public expenditure minister Brendan Howlin were upbeat, there was no triumphalism on display. And rightly not, given the pain in recent years. And the struggles to come. 

And we shouldn't forget the Ireland will still be paying the bailout back for many years after it ends on Sunday. 

Here's some key points from the briefing

• It's not just the end of the bailout that's historic. Howlin suggested the Irish banking crisis was the most dangerous time for Ireland since the state was created (in the 1920s). By the end, Noonan had declared it was the worst since the Famine (mid-19th Century).

As with the famine, the emigration seen in recent years could scar Ireland for many more years unless it can lure people back. 

• Ending the bailout is "not the end of the road". Ireland has already announced a new round of spending cuts and tax rises for next year, in the 2014 budget announced recently. Noonan was clear that further cuts lie ahead if Ireland is to lower its deficit to 3% by 2015.

This isn't the end of the road. This is a very significant milestone on the road...But we must continue with the same types of policies.

( Civil servants have already been outlining the cuts to the world's media).

• But it's goodbye, almost, to the Troika. The financial markets can be a nasty place when you lose the confidence of investors. But one good thing about bond traders is that they just want their money back (with a profit). They don't also tell you how to run your country. 

• The eurozone has changed a lot since 2010. Noonan reminded the press conference that three years, the idea of forcing losses from failed banks on senior creditors was anathema. Now it's official policy. Too late for the Irish taxpayer - who must keep hoping for some retrospective help for taking 'one for the team' in 2011.

• Kick a politician where it really hurts - in the ballot box. Chanting on the streets wins headlines and gets the media attention (guilty, M'Lud), but the message from Ireland is that if you really want to make your leaders suffer, you kick them out of office. Hard.

Brendan Howlin has got the message, talking about the democratic riot in 2011 when the government was thrown out on its ear. 

• Better times bring new problems, especially for coalitions. Noonan and Howlin maintained a united front today, but there's clearly the danger of a rift between the two coalition partners over fiscal policy.

The centre-right Fine Gael is inclined towards cutting income tax; Labour favours increased spending. The classic political tussle, which couldn't take place while the Troika were calling the shots.

Henry McDonald's news story from Dublin is being updated now.

And on that note, I'm going to suspend the blog. We'll re-open it if there are any major developments. Thanks for all the comments (well worth a read as ever). GW.

1.24pm GMT

Irish civil servants: more cuts to come

The politicians have departed Government Buildings to their constituencies, with Michael Noonan heading off to his native Limerick this evening (Henry McDonald writes)

But the top civil servants who run their departments are briefing the world's media on how savings and cuts will continue even in the absence of the IMF-EU Troika.

Public sector trade unions have made an agreement to protect jobs by reducing the state's pay bill, they said. 

Top officials across various Irish government departments have revealed that €1bn will be taken off the pay and pensions bill in the state sector.

1.03pm GMT

Fianna Fáil: Brussels will still be watching Ireland

The main opposition party in the Republic broadly welcomed the news that the IMF and EU Troika officials were flying home, reports Henry McDonald.

Fianna Fáil Finance spokesman Michael McGrath described Ireland's exit from the bailout programme as a significant milestone for the country.

However, he warned that there are significant challenges ahead for the economy.

McGrath said the country will continue to be subjected to "extensive external surveillance" by the Troika and by other international parties to ensure that the economic recovery beds down and takes root firmly.

Henry adds:

Generally speaking Fianna Fáil has backed the radical cost cutting measures imposed by the IMF-EU over the last three years.

The party that once dominated Irish politics have to tread carefully because the public - both at the 2011 general election and still to this day - blame their profligacy while in government from 1997 for fuelling the credit boom that led in part to the crash.

Updated at 1.03pm GMT

12.56pm GMT

Alan McQuaid, chief economist at Merrion Stockbrokers in Dublin, says it's too early to declare Ireland's economic problems over:

He told Reuters:

They have to be prudent. You can't just cut taxes for the sake of it.

It's a good story for the EU and it's a good story for us (but) we're still at the mercy of global factors.

Updated at 12.56pm GMT

12.51pm GMT

Here's Press Association's take on the press conference to mark the end of Ireland's bailout (see 10.40am onwards for highlights).

The heroes and heroines of Ireland's international bailout programme were the ordinary people, the country's finance minister has said.

As the once financially-crippled nation marked its exit from the EU/IMF €85 loan programme, Michael Noonan said those who have suffered the most were the hundreds of thousands who lost their jobs and homes, and young people who were forced to emigrate.

"The real heroes and heroines of the story are the Irish people," Mr Noonan said.

"They have had their taxes increased, they have had their services cut drastically, some of them including public servants have had very serious pay cuts.

"Everybody has had cuts in their pensions as well. But they have continued to supported the Government."

The country will officially exit the programme on December 15 and re-enter the money markets.

Ireland's finances, budgets and policies have been under intense scrutiny since the country agreed to a massive loan package in 2010.

Its debt masters, a Troika of the International Monetary Fund (IMF), the European Central Bank and European Commission, have carried out 12 intense reviews over the last three years and imposed a series of tough targets. All of which were met by the state. 

Updated at 1.04pm GMT

12.41pm GMT

Eamon Gilmore, the leader of Ireland's Labour party (and the country's foreign and trade minister) , has echoed Michael Noonan and Brendan Howlin by acknowledging how the Irish people have suffered since 2010: 

12.21pm GMT

12.00pm GMT

11.50am GMT

The final question is delivered in Irish Gaelic -- the reporter helpfully explains that he's asking about retrospective bank recapitalisation. As the minister replied in Irish Gaelic (quite right too), I don't know what he said. Sorry.

That's the end of the press conference. Presumably the press pack will be racing to book a restaurant for tonight....

11.46am GMT

Brendan Howlin's description of Ireland's 'democratic riot' in 2011 amused one Irish hack in the press conference, reports our own Henry McDonald:

One of the local journalists raises an alternative explanation to our German colleague asking once again why the Irish failed to riot during the crisis unlike their Greek or Spanish counterparts. "Because we are too f****** lazy!"

This produces some sniggers but Minister Howlin believes there was a democratic riot in the ballot box back in 2011 when the previous Fianna Fáil government sustained the heaviest electoral defeat in its history. 

While there some truth in this latter explanation as well as the patriotism of the Irish people in the face of the crisis, economic reality dictated there would be no widespread disorder in the streets, argues Henry:

Most people had too much invested in terms of property (much of it in negative equity), personal debt and jobs (or lack of them) to be rioting and causing disturbances in the state. The Republic has proven itself to be a stable albeit relatively conservative nation in the way it dealt with the crash, the bail out and the loss of economic sovereignty.

Updated at 12.00pm GMT

11.43am GMT

Minister Howlin: Ireland had a democratic riot

The German media are out in force in Dublin -asking why there were no riots during the bailout, as seen in other crisis-hit countries?

Howlin says that Ireland had a democratic riot -- in 2011 when the people threw out the government and elected the current coalition.

The senior partner in the government (Fianna Fáil) was "not only put out of office but devastated", and its junior partner (the Greens) was completely obliterated. 

People had their venting, their riot, but they did it in the polling booth. And that message has not been lost on us.

Howlin suggests that the Irish people weren't prepared to put their heads in the sand, or pretend there was a magic formula. 

Maybe we are used to setbacks, he adds.

"But we knew that this crisis would bring us down unless we addressed it."

11.41am GMT

Over to Henry again:

The Finance Minister compares the crisis as the greatest since the Famine when millions died in the mid 19th century potato blight and millions emigrated from British ruled Ireland.

Earlier his colleague Minister Howlin had compared the crash and the bail as the worst period since the Irish state was founded after 1921. 

Updated at 11.41am GMT

11.35am GMT

Michael Noonan pays tribute to the sacrifice made by the public since Ireland suffered "the biggest crisis since the famine".

11.34am GMT

Another question about whether anything has really changed by the end of the bailout. Aren't we just 'celebrating' three years of austerity?

Howlin explains that they key difference is that Ireland will no longer be bound to a single lender, which could make clear demands in return for providing funds. 

11.33am GMT

Asked about the eurozone's growth prospects by a reporter from a German newspaper, Brendan Howlin replies that Germany could do its bit to help --- he hopes that the next Berlin administration will help to stimulate its own domestic economy.

11.31am GMT

Does Ireland hope that its credit rating could be returned to investment grade?

Michael Noonan points out that Moody's is the only agency that rates Ireland as 'Junk' - we'd hope that they take another look at us in the new year. 

He adds that Ireland is now borrowing at lower interest rates than when it had a AAA rating. Ratings are one thing, but the way markets work can be different he adds (a polite way of suggesting we shouldn't flap about these dratted rating agencies?)

He's right too -- Ireland can borrow at just 3.5% per annum for 10 years, according to its bond yields.

11.28am GMT

A reminder that the press conference is being streamed here.

11.27am GMT

More fiscal consolidation ahead

Phil Aldrick of the Times asks whether Ireland will still need hefty budget cuts in the years ahead despite leaving the bailout.

Noonan confirms that it will -- saying ' we are committed to further fiscal consolidation', to get the deficit down to 3% by 2015 (that's the target set by Brussels)

Updated at 1.47pm GMT

11.26am GMT

Back on tax, and Noonan reiterates that his party is keen to lower income tax, but realises that the overall tax burden cannot be cut.

11.23am GMT

Brendan Howlin reiterates that the reform agenda will continue. He will announce new public sector reforms in January.

This second wave will focus on delivering better services for citizens, he adds.

11.22am GMT

More from Henry, on the minister's answer to his question on Ireland's domestic demand:

Finance Minister Michael Noonan sounded upbeat about rising consumer demand, which has been one of the weakest sectors of the Irish economy since the crash.

Noonan insisted that demand was building up again and that the exit from the bail out would increase general confidence in consumers. 

He said all the data indicated that people are prepared to spend more.

His Cabinet colleague Brendan Howlin quipped "try booking a restaurant tonight in Dublin" when asked about the weakness of consumer spending in the domestic economy during the crisis. 

Oh, and Henry assures me he'd never dare to expense a meal in a swanky Dublin eatery -- some prices give the impression that the crisis never happened.

11.19am GMT

Noonan: The eurozone is stronger now

Do the ministers have advice for other countries who are still in bailouts?

No, not particularly, Noonan replies. Spain has exited its programme too (which gave support for its banks), he says. There's a lot of confidence that Portugal will exit in 2014.

Slovenia also looks capable of fixing its banks without needing international help. The Greek position is getting better.

And Ireland is exiting its bailout this weekend.

The phase of additional European countries going into [bailout] programmes, and the countries in programmes having concerns over their situation, is over.

The eurozone is quite strong again

Huge changes have taken place since we started addressing our own problems in Ireland

The euro is worth holding onto, and it will deliver prosperity in the future, Noonan concludes.

Updated at 11.20am GMT

11.13am GMT

Noonan: confidence is fragile

A question from my colleague Henry McDonald -- how will leaving the bailout programme end the "consumer chill factor" and stimulate domestic demand?

"Try and book a restaurant in Dublin tonight", shoots back Brendan Howlin (put it on expenses, Henry!). In other words, consumers are spending again.

Michael Noonan also claims there is an upturn -- saying VAT receipts are above target at present.

But the Irish finance minister also concedes that any optimism is wafer-thin - and could be snapped by another crisis overseas.

The recovery is fragile now, he says, it would be easy to scare people. "Any international event could stop what's happening".

11.08am GMT

Does the end of the bailout programme mean there will be more political tensions between the coalition partners?

Brendan Howlin says that Labour's relationship with Fine Gael in the current coalition is the best he has known in his career.

He says that the government, elected in 2011, walked into an existential crisis over Ireland's future --which was "probably the worst crisis" since the creation of the Irish state itself.

There will be lively debate over the future of Ireland, he adds.

Noonan agrees, saying he wants to work with opposition parties as well as Ireland faces the future. There can be no repeat of the years before the boom:

We can't go mad again. Even if we had the resources it wouldn't be the right way to go.

Updated at 11.14am GMT

11.02am GMT

Key event

Next question: Was Jean-Claude Trichet unfair when he blocked Ireland's plan to "burn senior bondholders in 2011", and is Dublin's relationship with Mario Draghi (who replaced Trichet as current ECB president) better?

Noonan replies that when the eurozone crisis began, the people in senior positions were the people who had helped design the single currency, and struggled to change their view.

They were averse to change.

Trichet felt that senior bond holders were untouchable -- Ireland disagreed, but couldn't persuade him. Today, though, the eurozone has changed its position and now believes creditors (not taxpayers) should pay when a bank fails.

He say Trichet was still a good central bank governor, but hails Draghi's for his new approach - giving a "fillip" to the eurozone. It also helps that there is closer fiscal integration.

Noonan says he's also confident that Ireland can bring its national debt down towards the eurozone average.

10.59am GMT

Some early reaction from Ireland correspondent Henry McDonald:

It is interesting that Irish Finance Minister Michael Noonan has repeated the "heroes" theme first raised by his Cabinet colleague Richard Bruton earlier this morning.

"The real heroes and heroines are the Irish people," Minister Noonan said close to the start of the press conference in Government Buildings. 

It will be a theme accentuated throughout this weekend right up to the Taoiseach's speech to the nation live on television on Sunday evening. 

The Fine Gael-Labour coalition are doing humble in recognition of the pain the Irish people endured without Greek-style protests or mass demonstrations Spanish-style in the face of austerity cuts. 

By praising the populace as "heroes and heroines" the government are hoping they can appeal to the stoical patriotism that has partly resulted in no widespread social disorder in the face of the cuts imposed by the IMF-EU Troika. 

10.57am GMT

Another question -- for Brendan Howlin (the Labour minister). There has been talk from (Fine Gael's) Michael Noonan about tax cuts, but where would you like to see spending raised?

Howlin seems keen to avoid a disagreement -- saying it is too early to think in detail about the issue, but he'd like to see more help for hard-working, coping families.

Noonan chips in too- saying his party still see tax cuts as an instrument to create economic growth.

10.53am GMT

We need to get credit flowing in the Irish economy, says Noonan.

10.51am GMT

Noonan adds that the government's key focus now is to grow the economy to create "jobs for our people".

10.49am GMT

On to questions - the first from a Danish journalist -- how will things change on Monday?

Things won't change straight away, Michael Noonan replies. But people will know that their politicians will be taking decisions on their own, rather than in partnership with the Troika. 

Updated at 10.50am GMT

10.48am GMT

Brendan Howlin also says Ireland must make reforms to become a more open economy,.

We have a lot of work to do, but we can take the next steps with confidence.... he adds.

10.48am GMT

Howlin says the bailout exit is "a huge testament to the fortitude and forbearance" of the people of Ireland, and their determination "to put things right for them and their children".

Future generations owe them a huge debt, he says. 

10.46am GMT

Now, expenditure minister Brendan Howlin speaks - saying that in 2010 many people never though this day would come.

10.45am GMT

Noonan says the worst suffering has been experienced by those who lost their jobs in the last three years, and those who were forced to leave the country to find work. 

We want to encourage our very bright emigrants too come back, he adds

10.43am GMT

The real heroes and heroines of the Irish bailout story are the men and women who have coped with spending cuts, tax rises and other measures implemented over the last three years.

This isn't the end of the road, but it is a very significant milestone on the road.

Ireland's deficit is still too high, and so is the debt - it needs to be made 'even more sustainable;.

10.41am GMT

Finance Michael Noonan begins, saying Ireland has completed over 270 actions since signing up its bailout three years ago.

He says he doesn't want to look back, but reminds the press conference that the previous government had to seek help when it was locked out of the markets.

10.38am GMT

Looks like the BBC News website will be streaming this morning's press conference on Ireland leaving its bailout, here.

10.29am GMT

Minister: Poorly troika officials shocked by Irish medical costs

Dublin correspondent Henry McDonald has been hearing from another cabinet minister, this time Labour's minister for social protection, Joan Burton (Labour are the junior partner in the coalition with Fine Gael)

Burton has given some interesting insights into the relationship between her and the IMF-EU Troika officials who for the last three years have overseen the running of the Irish economy.

The Labour minister defended the Irish minimum wage of which the IMF-EU Troika were "not huge fans."

She says that the foreign economic experts were shocked and astonished when they had to pay €50 to €60 just to see a doctor because they kept picking up colds and flu while on constant flights into Ireland.

It was then they understood why a minimum wage was needed to help those in work in Ireland who have to pay huge costs for medical treatment including visits to their GP, Burton says.

In the early days of the three year bail out programme Burton says the Troika had a single approached spelled out in three letters - CUT.

One of the aspects of Irish social welfare she agreed with the Troika on was the need to reform the system from a "passive social welfare system into a public employment service to help to get people back to work and education."

Henry explains the political ramifications of the end of the bailout programme :

Politically, for Labour this bailout exit will be some comfort to a party that has taken a hammering in the opinion polls over the last three years. 

Its support has plunged to below 10% in recent polls and only a significant and tangible turnaround in economic fortunes could save it from heavy losses in the next general election. 

Despite leaving the bail out programme, Bruton stresses that "We have to have a continuing tightness on finance."

There will be, she predicts, a "modest prosperity" in Ireland rather than a return to the heady days of the Celtic Tiger boom when the country gorged on cheap credit and invested in an overheated property sector. 

Updated at 10.32am GMT

10.13am GMT

Heads-up: Ireland's finance minister, Michael Noonan, and minister for public expenditure, Brendan Howlin, will hold a briefing on Ireland's bailout exit in around 15 minutes time (at 10.30am GMT).

It should be streamed online here. 

10.01am GMT

Among the Irish business figures welcoming the bailout exit is Colm Tracey, the founder of 'eishtech', a call company centre based in Waterford and Wexford.

In 2010 the Belfast born entrepreneur was made redundant when Talk Talk pulled out of its Irish operation resulting in 575 job losses. 

He will soon employ 950 workers of his own by the middle of 2014, he reveals. 

I was forced to take on contract work in London and had to fly every Monday morning on the red eye from Dublin airport.

But my partners and I have turned it around after we started trading with our own company in 2011 and started winning contracts from British telecoms companies.

Tracey's experience of the banking system is unlike many of his counterparts who complain that the bailed out banks are not lending money to SMEs, saying:

Our banks work with us I'm pleased to say, I can't speak for anyone else.

9.51am GMT

The Irish finance ministry has tweeted a timeline of the last three years:

9.42am GMT

"Why didn't the Irish riot?"

A German journalist has just asked Irish employment minister Richard Bruton why the Irish did not go out and riot on the streets like their counterparts in Greece and Spain (reports Henry McDonald from this morning's press conference).

Bruton replies that most people understood that in an economy that relies on exports they accepted the challenges of austerity.

He says there was a "patriotism in the way people approached this crisis."

9.23am GMT

Richard Bruton, the Irish Employment minister, is pointing to Ireland's strength in the hi-tech and food sector as evidence of the Republic exporting its way out of the crisis.

Speaking inside the government buildings a few minutes ago, Bruton says the government has created a €2.5 billion in loans for new businesses to fill the void created by Irish banks reluctant to lend to SMEs and entrepreneurs.

Bruton described enterprises and workers as the "true heroes" who battled their way through the economic crisis.

He said that the fact Intel's new chip was manufactured in Ireland was a "mark of the journey" Ireland had been on over the last three years. 

The minister said that over the last year there had been a 4% increase in private sector employment but acknowledged that unemployment was still high at 12.5% of the overall workforce.

  • On the taxpayer rescued Irish banks, Bruton accepted that the banking sector are "not lending to the levels that we would like."
  • He said bank refusal rates on loans to business are still high compared to other parts of Europe.
  • Bruton however stressed that refusal rates over the last two and a half years had fallen from 30% to 20%.

The banks are some of the biggest hate figures among the general population after tens of billions of euros were pumped into a sector that got into lethal debt levels because they were leading vast sums to builders and property speculators. 

9.18am GMT

9.17am GMT

Irish entrepreneur optimistic about the future

Among those attending a government breakfast briefing in Dublin were a number of entrepreneurs who have kept doing business throughout the stormy atmosphere of the last few years (writes Henry McDonald).

They include Dr Kieran Curran, the 33 year old CEO of Gencell Biosystems which supplies genetic testing for big pharma companies in the United States.

Dr Curran employs 40 graduates at his plant in Limerick City which he established in 2011 in the middle of the IMF-EU bail out programme. A creator of real jobs in the economy, he insists that the bail out exit will have tangible effects on his business which he is trying to grow across the planet.

Dr Curran explains:

"We were in China last month and were asked about the state of Ireland. And we were able to tell that our country is managing its debt, that it is financially competent. These things matter in potential markets such as China." 

He also has a family story that is typical of so many Irish SMEs across the state during the economic crisis. 

His family run a windows and doors construction company which after the 2007-2008 crash had to downsize their workforce from 65 to 20. However Dr Curran said there has been a "real turnaround" in the family's business this year.

"They have now got the workforce back up to 55 and in the last three months there has been a noticeable upturn in business," Dr Curran adds. 

Updated at 9.17am GMT

9.03am GMT

Sinn Fein: 'Troika mindset remains firm'

Back to Ireland, where opposition politicians are warning that the country faces tough times despite the end of the bailout.

Sinn Fein's Finance spokesman Pearse Doherty said that while the Troika of IMF, EU and European Central Bank officials were leaving Dublin, "the Troika mindset remains firm in government buildings".

Doherty predicted that there would be further austerity cuts long after the bail out programme was over and the Troika was gone. 

"They bailed out the banks and unfortunately over the three years it was the Irish people that suffered."

Updated at 9.03am GMT

8.59am GMT

Confirmation that the eurozone economy remains fragile: the Standard & Poor's rating agency has reaffirmed Italy's credit rating at BBB with a negative outlook. That means a one in three chance of a downgrade next year.

S&P said:

Italy's growth prospects remain weak, while the net general government debt burden continues to be among the highest of all the sovereigns we rate.

8.58am GMT

8.50am GMT

This tweet also gives a sense of the mood in Ireland today, as it looks beyond its €85bn bailout.

8.48am GMT

Sir Christopher Pissarides, who won the economics Nobel prize in 2010, said the bailout exit is a "great moment" for Ireland. He believes its government should be congratulated for completing the programme on time.

But Pissarides also disputes that Ireland's experience proves that the eurozone's medicine of hefty fiscal cutbacks can work, as its crisis was caused by its banking sector - not its wider economy.

We should regard Ireland as a country that can give lessons on the banking sector...…. but it is not a good example of how to reform the economy as they we did not need to reform the Irish economy too much.

Michael O'Sullivan from Credit Suisse also pointed to the mounting social problems in Ireland, telling the Today Programme that:

Ireland is a lesson - no country would want to go through what we've seen in the last three or four years.

8.32am GMT

Radio 4's Today Programme has also been covering Ireland's bailout exit. Gavin Hewitt, the BBC's Europe editor, reports that some eurocrats are already using it as an example that Brussels' approach to the crisis can work.

As Hewitt put it said:

Some EU officials are already saying - look, Ireland can do it.

But he also points to the social impact -- with homelessness up, and fears that the poorest 10% in Ireland have lost a fifth of their income.

8.22am GMT

Sky News's Ed Conway has summed up the economic picture in Ireland today:

The currency is still intact, despite real fears, culminating last summer, that it would face implosion.

And the economic numbers are starting, finally, to turn in Ireland's favour.

But it's hard to revel in this when you take even a moment to examine the plight of the country.

Whether you view it in statistical or human terms, Ireland has faced a genuine depression over the past six years.

Between 2008 and the end of 2010, the country's economic output - in other words the amount of income its entire economy generated - shrank by a tenth.

House prices halved since 2007 - a bigger fall than has been seen in any developed economy in recent memory.

If the property market was the engine for the economy before the crisis, it is now essentially non-existent.

More here: Ireland Struggles On Brink Of Bailout

8.21am GMT

EU commissioner Olli Rehn reminded Ireland last night that their path into austerity began when the last government took the fateful decision to guarantee its banking sector's huge toxic debts.

That's via my colleague Henry McDonald, who sets the scene in Dublin:

A host of government ministers, the CEOs of several major Irish companies and the head of the country's Industrial Development Authority are lining up to talk up the impact of the Republic exiting the bail out programme this weekend.

On this unseasonably mild but dark December morning in Dublin, the ministers are holding a series of briefings to explain what leaving the IMF-EU multi billion euro programme means not only for Ireland but the whole of the Eurozone.

Ahead of a momentous weekend the EU's vice-president Olli Rehn told RTE television last that one of the biggest mistakes of the previous government led by Fianna Fáil was to grant a blanket guarantee to shore the country 's debt ridden banks - one of the key parts of the economy that promoted Ireland to go cap in hand to Europe and the IMF.

Despite restoring economic sovereignty there is no sense in Dublin or across the state of any euphoria over exiting the bail out.

With consumers, many of them in negative equity due to the disastrous property crash of 2007-2008 , still reluctant to spend let alone borrow, the population remains cautious about its finances and its future.

8.00am GMT

Ireland's bailout programme comes to an end

Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of events across the world economy, the financial markets, the eurozone and the business world.

Ireland is poised to make history this weekend, becoming the first eurozone country to exit a bailout.

Three years after signing up for an €85bn rescue deal and painful austerity plan, Ireland will leave the programme behind on Sunday night.

It's a genuinely notable moment for a country that has swallowed swingeing spending cuts, tax rises and slashed wages since its banking sector spectacularly imploded in winter 2010.

The Dublin government insists that the fundamental problems of the Irish economy have been fixed, leaving the country now facing a positive future.

By some measures, the programme was a success -- Ireland is no longer locked out of the international markets, and can borrow again.

But behind the satisfaction, Ireland still faces tough economic problems -- having finally struggled out of recession earlier this year. And the human cost of the austerity demanded in return for the bailout has been huge. Around 300,000 people have left the country since 2010, and the unemployment rate has risen over 12%. 

The poster child of Europe's response to the crisis may be back on its feet, but it will be walking gingerly for some time. 

Various events are taking place in the Irish capital over the next few days to mark the moment. Finance ministers will hold a press conference later this morning, where they could outline a mid-term economic strategy for the next three years.

We'll be tracking the developments in Ireland, and beyond, through the day.....

fields.bodyText: Update: we've just launched an open thread where readers can discuss Ireland's bailout exit. But while finance minister Michael Noonan and public expenditure minister Brendan Howlin were upbeat, there was no triumphalism on display. And rightly not, given the pain in recent years. And the struggles to come. And we shouldn't forget the Ireland will still be paying the bailout back for many years after it ends on Sunday. Here's some key points from the briefing • It's not just the end of the bailout that's historic. Howlin suggested the Irish banking crisis was the most dangerous time for Ireland since the state was created (in the 1920s). By the end, Noonan had declared it was the worst since the Famine (mid-19th Century). As with the famine, the emigration seen in recent years could scar Ireland for many more years unless it can lure people back. • Ending the bailout is "not the end of the road". Ireland has already announced a new round of spending cuts and tax rises for next year, in the 2014 budget announced recently. Noonan was clear that further cuts lie ahead if Ireland is to lower its deficit to 3% by 2015. This isn't the end of the road. This is a very significant milestone on the road...But we must continue with the same types of policies. ( Civil servants have already been outlining the cuts to the world's media). • But it's goodbye, almost, to the Troika. The financial markets can be a nasty place when you lose the confidence of investors. But one good thing about bond traders is that they just want their money back (with a profit). They don't also tell you how to run your country. • The eurozone has changed a lot since 2010. Noonan reminded the press conference that three years, the idea of forcing losses from failed banks on senior creditors was anathema. Now it's official policy. Too late for the Irish taxpayer - who must keep hoping for some retrospective help for taking 'one for the team' in 2011. • Kick a politician where it really hurts - in the ballot box. Chanting on the streets wins headlines and gets the media attention (guilty, M'Lud), but the message from Ireland is that if you really want to make your leaders suffer, you kick them out of office. Hard. Brendan Howlin has got the message, talking about the democratic riot in 2011 when the government was thrown out on its ear. • Better times bring new problems, especially for coalitions. Noonan and Howlin maintained a united front today, but there's clearly the danger of a rift between the two coalition partners over fiscal policy. The centre-right Fine Gael is inclined towards cutting income tax; Labour favours increased spending. The classic political tussle, which couldn't take place while the Troika were calling the shots. Henry McDonald's news story from Dublin is being updated now. And on that note, I'm going to suspend the blog. We'll re-open it if there are any major developments. Thanks for all the comments (well worth a read as ever). GW. The politicians have departed Government Buildings to their constituencies, with Michael Noonan heading off to his native Limerick this evening (Henry McDonald writes) But the top civil servants who run their departments are briefing the world's media on how savings and cuts will continue even in the absence of the IMF-EU Troika. Public sector trade unions have made an agreement to protect jobs by reducing the state's pay bill, they said. Top officials across various Irish government departments have revealed that €1bn will be taken off the pay and pensions bill in the state sector. The main opposition party in the Republic broadly welcomed the news that the IMF and EU Troika officials were flying home, reports Henry McDonald. Fianna Fáil Finance spokesman Michael McGrath described Ireland's exit from the bailout programme as a significant milestone for the country. However, he warned that there are significant challenges ahead for the economy. McGrath said the country will continue to be subjected to "extensive external surveillance" by the Troika and by other international parties to ensure that the economic recovery beds down and takes root firmly. Henry adds: Generally speaking Fianna Fáil has backed the radical cost cutting measures imposed by the IMF-EU over the last three years. The party that once dominated Irish politics have to tread carefully because the public - both at the 2011 general election and still to this day - blame their profligacy while in government from 1997 for fuelling the credit boom that led in part to the crash. Alan McQuaid, chief economist at Merrion Stockbrokers in Dublin, says it's too early to declare Ireland's economic problems over: He told Reuters: They have to be prudent. You can't just cut taxes for the sake of it. It's a good story for the EU and it's a good story for us (but) we're still at the mercy of global factors. Here's Press Association's take on the press conference to mark the end of Ireland's bailout (see 10.40am onwards for highlights). The heroes and heroines of Ireland's international bailout programme were the ordinary people, the country's finance minister has said. As the once financially-crippled nation marked its exit from the EU/IMF €85 loan programme, Michael Noonan said those who have suffered the most were the hundreds of thousands who lost their jobs and homes, and young people who were forced to emigrate. "The real heroes and heroines of the story are the Irish people," Mr Noonan said. "They have had their taxes increased, they have had their services cut drastically, some of them including public servants have had very serious pay cuts. "Everybody has had cuts in their pensions as well. But they have continued to supported the Government." The country will officially exit the programme on December 15 and re-enter the money markets. Ireland's finances, budgets and policies have been under intense scrutiny since the country agreed to a massive loan package in 2010. Its debt masters, a Troika of the International Monetary Fund (IMF), the European Central Bank and European Commission, have carried out 12 intense reviews over the last three years and imposed a series of tough targets. All of which were met by the state. Eamon Gilmore, the leader of Ireland's Labour party (and the country's foreign and trade minister) , has echoed Michael Noonan and Brendan Howlin by acknowledging how the Irish people have suffered since 2010: The final question is delivered in Irish Gaelic -- the reporter helpfully explains that he's asking about retrospective bank recapitalisation. As the minister replied in Irish Gaelic (quite right too), I don't know what he said. Sorry. That's the end of the press conference. Presumably the press pack will be racing to book a restaurant for tonight.... Brendan Howlin's description of Ireland's 'democratic riot' in 2011 amused one Irish hack in the press conference, reports our own Henry McDonald: One of the local journalists raises an alternative explanation to our German colleague asking once again why the Irish failed to riot during the crisis unlike their Greek or Spanish counterparts. "Because we are too f****** lazy!" This produces some sniggers but Minister Howlin believes there was a democratic riot in the ballot box back in 2011 when the previous Fianna Fáil government sustained the heaviest electoral defeat in its history. While there some truth in this latter explanation as well as the patriotism of the Irish people in the face of the crisis, economic reality dictated there would be no widespread disorder in the streets, argues Henry: Most people had too much invested in terms of property (much of it in negative equity), personal debt and jobs (or lack of them) to be rioting and causing disturbances in the state. The Republic has proven itself to be a stable albeit relatively conservative nation in the way it dealt with the crash, the bail out and the loss of economic sovereignty. The German media are out in force in Dublin -asking why there were no riots during the bailout, as seen in other crisis-hit countries? Howlin says that Ireland had a democratic riot -- in 2011 when the people threw out the government and elected the current coalition. The senior partner in the government (Fianna Fáil) was "not only put out of office but devastated", and its junior partner (the Greens) was completely obliterated. People had their venting, their riot, but they did it in the polling booth. And that message has not been lost on us. Howlin suggests that the Irish people weren't prepared to put their heads in the sand, or pretend there was a magic formula. Maybe we are used to setbacks, he adds. "But we knew that this crisis would bring us down unless we addressed it." Over to Henry again: The Finance Minister compares the crisis as the greatest since the Famine when millions died in the mid 19th century potato blight and millions emigrated from British ruled Ireland. Earlier his colleague Minister Howlin had compared the crash and the bail as the worst period since the Irish state was founded after 1921. Michael Noonan pays tribute to the sacrifice made by the public since Ireland suffered "the biggest crisis since the famine". Another question about whether anything has really changed by the end of the bailout. Aren't we just 'celebrating' three years of austerity? Howlin explains that they key difference is that Ireland will no longer be bound to a single lender, which could make clear demands in return for providing funds. Asked about the eurozone's growth prospects by a reporter from a German newspaper, Brendan Howlin replies that Germany could do its bit to help --- he hopes that the next Berlin administration will help to stimulate its own domestic economy. Does Ireland hope that its credit rating could be returned to investment grade? Michael Noonan points out that Moody's is the only agency that rates Ireland as 'Junk' - we'd hope that they take another look at us in the new year. He adds that Ireland is now borrowing at lower interest rates than when it had a AAA rating. Ratings are one thing, but the way markets work can be different he adds (a polite way of suggesting we shouldn't flap about these dratted rating agencies?) He's right too -- Ireland can borrow at just 3.5% per annum for 10 years, according to its bond yields. A reminder that the press conference is being streamed here. Phil Aldrick of the Times asks whether Ireland will still need hefty budget cuts in the years ahead despite leaving the bailout. Noonan confirms that it will -- saying ' we are committed to further fiscal consolidation', to get the deficit down to 3% by 2015 (that's the target set by Brussels) Back on tax, and Noonan reiterates that his party is keen to lower income tax, but realises that the overall tax burden cannot be cut. Brendan Howlin reiterates that the reform agenda will continue. He will announce new public sector reforms in January. This second wave will focus on delivering better services for citizens, he adds. More from Henry, on the minister's answer to his question on Ireland's domestic demand: Finance Minister Michael Noonan sounded upbeat about rising consumer demand, which has been one of the weakest sectors of the Irish economy since the crash. Noonan insisted that demand was building up again and that the exit from the bail out would increase general confidence in consumers. He said all the data indicated that people are prepared to spend more. His Cabinet colleague Brendan Howlin quipped "try booking a restaurant tonight in Dublin" when asked about the weakness of consumer spending in the domestic economy during the crisis. Oh, and Henry assures me he'd never dare to expense a meal in a swanky Dublin eatery -- some prices give the impression that the crisis never happened. Do the ministers have advice for other countries who are still in bailouts? No, not particularly, Noonan replies. Spain has exited its programme too (which gave support for its banks), he says. There's a lot of confidence that Portugal will exit in 2014. Slovenia also looks capable of fixing its banks without needing international help. The Greek position is getting better. And Ireland is exiting its bailout this weekend. The phase of additional European countries going into [bailout] programmes, and the countries in programmes having concerns over their situation, is over. The eurozone is quite strong again Huge changes have taken place since we started addressing our own problems in Ireland The euro is worth holding onto, and it will deliver prosperity in the future, Noonan concludes. A question from my colleague Henry McDonald -- how will leaving the bailout programme end the "consumer chill factor" and stimulate domestic demand? "Try and book a restaurant in Dublin tonight", shoots back Brendan Howlin (put it on expenses, Henry!). In other words, consumers are spending again. Michael Noonan also claims there is an upturn -- saying VAT receipts are above target at present. But the Irish finance minister also concedes that any optimism is wafer-thin - and could be snapped by another crisis overseas. The recovery is fragile now, he says, it would be easy to scare people. "Any international event could stop what's happening". Does the end of the bailout programme mean there will be more political tensions between the coalition partners? Brendan Howlin says that Labour's relationship with Fine Gael in the current coalition is the best he has known in his career. He says that the government, elected in 2011, walked into an existential crisis over Ireland's future --which was "probably the worst crisis" since the creation of the Irish state itself. There will be lively debate over the future of Ireland, he adds. Noonan agrees, saying he wants to work with opposition parties as well as Ireland faces the future. There can be no repeat of the years before the boom: We can't go mad again. Even if we had the resources it wouldn't be the right way to go. Next question: Was Jean-Claude Trichet unfair when he blocked Ireland's plan to "burn senior bondholders in 2011", and is Dublin's relationship with Mario Draghi (who replaced Trichet as current ECB president) better? Noonan replies that when the eurozone crisis began, the people in senior positions were the people who had helped design the single currency, and struggled to change their view. They were averse to change. Trichet felt that senior bond holders were untouchable -- Ireland disagreed, but couldn't persuade him. Today, though, the eurozone has changed its position and now believes creditors (not taxpayers) should pay when a bank fails. He say Trichet was still a good central bank governor, but hails Draghi's for his new approach - giving a "fillip" to the eurozone. It also helps that there is closer fiscal integration. Noonan says he's also confident that Ireland can bring its national debt down towards the eurozone average. "The real heroes and heroines are the Irish people," Minister Noonan said close to the start of the press conference in Government Buildings. It will be a theme accentuated throughout this weekend right up to the Taoiseach's speech to the nation live on television on Sunday evening. Various events are taking place in the Irish capital over the next few days to mark the moment. Finance ministers will hold a press conference later this morning, where they could outline a mid-term economic strategy for the next three years. We'll be tracking the developments in Ireland, and beyond, through the day.....

webTitle: Body-gripping shapewear transforms the look of party season outfits

fields.standfirst: Fashion retailers say sales of silhouette-improving shapewear have soared in the run-up to the Christmas party season
fields.body:
It's an American import popularised by Hollywood 'A' listers on the red carpet and offering a mind-boggling choice of silhouette-smoothing slips, knee-length "britches" and even full-length leggings to suck in bulging tummies and over-generous thighs.

Now UK retailers say sales of body-shaping underwear or "shapewear" have soared in the run-up to Christmas as women (the men's market is tiny) try to look their best in figure-hugging party outfits.

Department store John Lewis has reported a 150% increase in sales of the US brand Spanx alone – which promises shoppers that they've "got your butt covered".

Other retailers including Marks & Spencer, Topshop, Asda and Sainsbury's have followed suit with a range of more affordable items and are also reporting strong sales ahead of office parties and other seasonal celebrations.

Body-gripping shapewear has evolved from unflattering flesh-coloured Bridget Jones-style pants and eye-wateringly tight lycra (or spandex) to breathable girdles, waist-cinchers and strapless bodies.

Jo Hooper, head of womenswear at John Lewis, said state-of-art technology such as bonding and laser-cutting has "transformed" the product by banishing the seams, hems and bulky fastenings which have traditionally stood in the way of a streamlined silhouette. Improved fabrics also help the body to "breathe", while special shaping zones target specific problem areas.

Hooper noted that red carpet stars unwittingly revealing a tell-tale glimpse of Spanx included, most recently, actress Cate Blanchett: "Celebrities all look wonderful in it. If they can wear it, why not everyone else? Our sales figures show that loads of women do, even if they don't admit it. Shapewear is clearly becoming a mainstream item in women's wardrobes as they use it not just to give them a boost at a party or a wedding but to give them confidence at other times as well. Spanx is our best-seller and women can see that it does what it says on the box."

Spanx was founded in 2000 by American entrepreneur and now billionaire Sara Blakely, who launched the range after struggling to find the right underwear to wear under a pair of pale trousers. She cut the feet off a pair of tights and caused a commercial revolution in the lingerie world.

The Spanx range set tills ringing in the USA following the personal endorsement of Oprah Winfrey, since then the fashion for tight-fit 'body-con' dresses on both sides of the Atlantic has made shapewear – with many copycat brands – a universally popular trend.

High Street and online retailer Debenhams has seen a 10% increase in shapewear sales on the same time last year and a near doubling of sales between October and November this year in the run-up to the festive season.

And at Marks & Spencer – which sells 120 own-brand items of shapewear in its lingerie department – sales have increased by 75% in December

Soozie Jenkinson, M&S's head of lingerie design, said: "In the three weeks before Christmas, we expect to sell an amazing 10 shapewear items per minute as women prepare for the party season"

webTitle: Ireland becomes first country to exit eurozone bailout programme

fields.standfirst: 'We can't go mad again,' says finance minister Michael Noonan after describing crisis as country's worst since the potato famine
fields.body:
Three years after being saved from bankruptcy by a trio of international lenders with a €67.5bn loan, Ireland has become the first stricken eurozone state to exit its rescue programme.

Describing the crisis as the country's worst period since the potato famine, Ireland's finance minister said there must be no repeat of the debt-fuelled property spree that brought the Celtic Tiger boom to a disastrous end. "We can't go mad again," said Michael Noonan.

Ireland's announcement that it will not seek more funds from the International Monetary Fund, European commission and European Central Bank - with the rescue scheme to end formally on Sunday - was seized upon by the EC president, José Manuel Barroso, as evidence that the eurozone can stage a full recovery.

"Ireland's success sends an important message - that with determination and support from partner countries we can and will emerge stronger from this deep crisis," he said.

Greece, Cyprus and Portugal are still working through rescue programmes, which include external scrutiny of government budgets, while Spain has received funds to recapitalise its banks. Ireland's bailout - which came after the state guaranteeed the investments of depositors and bondholders in its stricken banks - was comprised of €22.5bn from each of the co-called "troika" members over three years, topped up to a total of €85bn with the country's cash reserves.

Having implemented the spending cuts, asset sales and reforms required under the bailout, Ireland has been embraced again by the debt markets that shut out the country at the turn of the decade. It has raised enough debt independently to fund itself into 2015 and has more than €20bn (£17bn) in the bank.

However relief that Ireland will officially exit the rescue programme on Sunday was tempered with warnings from Irish ministers that the policy of austerity must continue, in order to drive down the country's mountain of debt. Noonan said: "This isn't the end of the road. This is a very significant milestone on the road.

In its final report on Ireland's progress under the rescue scheme, published on Friday, the European commission said: "With public debt level at 124% of GDP in 2013, Ireland needs to continue with fiscal consolidation, reduce the private-sector debt overhang, and improve bank profitability to revive lending."

Cabinet ministers also lined up on Friday to praise the Irish people for stoically accepting three years of deep cuts to social welfare, state jobs and public sector wages as part of a programme of 270 separate reductions in state budgets.

Noonan suggested the crisis that pushed Ireland to the edge of financial disaster was the worst since the famine of the mid-19th century in which millions died or emigrated as potato blight wiped out Ireland's staple crop.

Asked how the exit from the bailout would impact on domestic demand – one of the weakest sectors in the Irish economy – Noonan's ministerial colleague Brendan Howlin interjected at the press conference in the Government Buildings: "Try booking a restaurant in Dublin tonight."

The minister who has had to deal most with IMF-EU officials over the last four years, Noonan, said they sometimes failed to appreciate the political pressures the Irish coalition was under.

"Most of the people who were involved in the background of the troika were very smart, very competent technocratic people but they weren't very good at politics," Noonan said.

Ireland surprised many observers last month by announcing that it would not apply for a precautionary credit line from the IMF - which could have allowed it access to the ECB's emergency rescue scheme in the event of a future crisis. Instead, the government was determined to show that it can stand on its own two feet.

On Europe's prospects as a whole, Noonan said: "The phase of additional European countries going into [bailout] programmes, and the countries in programmes having concerns over their situation, is over. The eurozone is quite strong again."

Noonan added: "The real heroes and heroines are the Irish people."

Earlier the employment minister, Richard Bruton, praised the way the Irish accepted their newly straitened circumstances without taking to the streets, as in Greece and Portugal, describing the "patriotism in the way people approached this crisis".

Among the ordinary citizens portrayed as the true heroes of the last three years there was a mixture of resignation and wariness over what the exit would mean for them.

Michael McMorrow, a self-employed Dubliner, said: "It does appear that there are small signs of improvement – unemployment going down a little, property market starting to move a little, dormant shop units waking up a little, the tide of new charity shops in Dún Laoghaire [a seaside town in the south Dublin suburbs] slowing down a little.

"I'd love to believe that leaving the bailout is genuinely a step into the light, and maybe it is, but I'm too scarred to raise my hopes just yet."

But Martin Shannon, a 31-year-old bookseller from south Dublin, said he had already noticed an upturn in consumer demand even before the country left the bailout.

"We'll be in control of our finances more than we have been for the last few years, but I'm indifferent as to whether that's actually a good thing. Wasn't it ourselves who dug the hole in the first place? Or at least allowed the hole to be dug on our land.

"Working in a bookshop, I'm used to having a grim outlook. Paying tax, and with more taxes and charges looming in the new year, it's hard to get excited about this. However, there is one thing that gives me a bit of hope, and indicates to me that things might be getting better. I've noticed that our turnover in the bookshop is up around 10% on this time last year. Customers seem more relaxed and are spending a little more easily, pointedly mentioning the price of books a little less frequently," Shannon said.
